main event: Unidentified flying objects were observed multiple times in Greenville, North Carolina, on February 6, 1954, and February 15, 1954. The objects were described as round, bright white lights that moved rapidly across the sky and were also observed on radar.
interesting points: Objects were observed maneuvering rapidly and violating prohibited areas, as well as disappearing from sight in a short period of time.
Witnesses reported seeing solid balls with brilliant orange colors and twin parallel 'tails'.
Radar tracking records were obtained, showing unidentified targets in the area during the sightings, which adds credibility to the reports.

The sighting on February 6, 1954, included witnesses reporting a metallic, circular object of approximately 40-50 feet in diameter, traveling at a high rate of speed and leaving no physical evidence behind.
The incidents were investigated under Project Blue Book, a U.S. Air Force program for investigating UFO sightings, and a detailed analysis of the sightings was conducted.
result: The sightings remain unexplained, and the unidentified flying objects could not be positively identified as meteorological, astronomical, or any other known phenomena.
sighted object: Unidentified flying objects described as round, bright white lights, solid balls with brilliant orange colors, and metallic, circular objects.
witnesses: Multiple witnesses, including military personnel and radar operators.
photographs: The report includes radar and sonar images but no clear photographs of the UFOs.
